title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: Love and marriage came over the country like a divine opiate, inspired,I believe, by that love story in the White House, which culminated onJune 2, 1886, in the wedding of Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland. Never in myknowledge were there so many weddings all over the United States asduring the week when this official wedding took place in the WhiteHouse.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: They stepped out into the strip of garden presently,while Mrs. Sage was taking off her bonnet, and there,leaning over the low wall at the end, Gilbert toldher the news. He was going back to Inch Gow and tolive in the "White House" again; he was master of itnow; half of those early day-dreams had come topass, but Nell did not feel nearly so sure about theother half—her half. Mr. Priestley had given him avery good appointment on the works, where he wasto be his right hand and assistant generally; " andwithout boasting, we know what that means some day.

title: Recollections of a Long Life; An Autobiography
author: Cuyler, Theodore L. (Theodore Ledyard)
snippet: We spent but a few moments with Mr. Lincoln, and when we came outmy mother exclaimed: "Oh, what a cruelty to keep that man here! Did youever see such a sad face in your life?" I never had, and I have giventhis account of my call on him in order that my readers may not onlyunderstand what democratic customs then prevailed in the White House,but may get some faint idea of the terribly trying life that Mr. Lincolnled.

title: Recollections of a Long Life; An Autobiography
author: Cuyler, Theodore L. (Theodore Ledyard)
snippet: The shockingly careless appearance of the White House proved thatwhatever may have been Mrs. Lincoln's other good qualities, she hadn'tearned the compliment which the Yankee farmer paid to his wife when hesaid: "Ef my wife haint got an ear fer music, she's got an eye ferdirt." When we reached the room of the President's Private Secretary,my old friend, the Rev. Mr. Neill, of St. Paul's, told me that it wasmilitary court day, when the President had to decide upon cases of armydiscipline that came before him and when he received no calls.

title: Recollections of a Long Life; An Autobiography
author: Cuyler, Theodore L. (Theodore Ledyard)
snippet: I mention this as an illustration of his marvelous memory; henever forgot a face or a name or the slightest incident. My mother waswith me at the Smithsonian, and as she was extremely desirous to see thePresident I took her over to the White House late on the followingafternoon. In those war times, when Washington was a camp, the WhiteHouse looked more like an army barracks than the Presidential mansion.

title: Recollections of a Long Life; An Autobiography

title: The Dew of Their Youth
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)

She isthinking of that once open space by the Greyfriars where, to theaccompaniment of keen chisel-stroke and dull mallet-thud, once on a dayshe came to me, more dream-like than my dream, and said, "I have foundit, the Little White House!"

title: The Dew of Their Youth
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: So strong was the feeling that Irma would gladly have returned beforeour time to the little White House above the meadow flats, and to theview of the Pentlands turning a solid green butt towards the Archers'Hall of the Guid Toon of Edinburgh.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: "May 21, 1896. This morning when I entered President Cleveland's    room at the White House, he said: 'Good morning, I have been    thinking of you this morning.'

title: The Dew of Their Youth
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: So strong was the feeling that Irma would gladly have returned beforeour time to the little White House above the meadow flats, and to theview of the Pentlands turning a solid green butt towards the Archers'Hall of the Guid Toon of Edinburgh.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: Made my last call this afternoon on Mrs. Cleveland. Found her amid a group of distinguished ladies, and unhappy at the    thought of leaving the White House, which had been her home off and    on for nearly eight years. Her children have already gone to    Princeton, which is to be her new home.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: And so the White House fortunes went steadilydown-hill. Gilbert drifted farther and farther awayfrom his own fireside—sometimes to Edinburgh, sometimes to Glasgow.

title: A holiday tour in Europe.
author: Cook, Joel
snippet: There are tall, weird, old houses on either hand, and among them the narrow home of John Knox, a strange-looking building, adjoining a church. Nearly every house in these two streets is historically famous, and out of these streets run curious alleys known as closes, and bearing quaint names, such as " Big Jock's close," " Bakehouse close," " Strathie's close," etc. " White House close" leads to a famous inn. All these old houses, some of which are sad-looking rookeries, were in former days the homes of the nobility.

title: A knight templar abroad;
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: ^^^^Y this time, our anxiety to reach Holyrood Pal- ^^ ace becomes intense, and we can hardly give due attention to what we see around us, but as the Canongate  is the last portion of the High Street between the Castle and Palace (the High Street bearing the same relation to these historic hills that Pennsylvania Avenue  does to the Capitol and the White House at Washington,  the President being familiarly known as " the man at the other end of the Avenue"), and there are several things of interest to be seen here, we will stop a few minutes as we pass by, at any rate. The Canongate was begun in the early part of the twelfth- century, (and its antique and time-stained buildings, indeed, look much older than that) by the Augustine Canons of Holyrood, who ruled as a burgh of regality, under a charter from King David I., and many of the houses yet retain the venerable appearance of the ancient court end of the city.

title: A Holiday Tour in Europe. Described in a series of letters written for The Public Ledger, etc
author: Cook, Joel.
snippet: Thereare tall, weird, old houses on either hand, and among themthe narrow home of John Knox, a strange-looking building,adjoining a church. Nearly every house in these two streetsis historically famous, and out of these streets run curiousalleys known as closes, and bearing quaint names, such as" Big Jock's close," " Bakehouse close," " Strathie's close,"etc. " White House close" leads to a famous inn. All theseold houses, some of which are sad-looking rookeries, were informer days the homes of the nobility.

title: Sketches of travel:
author: King, Horatio
snippet: Pere La Chaise, the Cemetery made famous by the writings of Lamartine ere special attention had been directed to the embellishment of burial places in the United States, is situated on an eminence in the eastern suburbs of the city, corresponding somewhat with our Congressional Cemetery, while the Arc de Triomphe, on the western side, may, in point of location, be regarded as somewhat corresponding with our White House, or more nearly with the Heights of Georgetown. The great bulk of the city lies principally on lower ground, between Pere La Chaise and the Arc de Triomphe, extending to the north and south of the Seine, which, in its course through the city, separates and forms two considerable  islands just east of the Louvre.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: "I was glad I was present that day, when Mr. Andrew Carnegie decided    upon the gift of a library to the city of Washington. I was in one    of the rooms of the White House talking with Governor Lowndes, of    Maryland, and Mr. B.H. Warner, of Washington, who was especially    interested in city libraries. Mr. Carnegie entered at the opposite    end of the room.

title: Shandygaff :
author: Morley, Christopher
snippet: This position I filled for some months in a way highly satisfactory to the Government in power. It is particularly gratifying to me to remember that one evening, after I had worked unusually hard at the Census Office, the late President McKinley himself nodded and smiled to me as I passed through the White House grounds on my way home from toil. He had heard of my work that day, I had no doubt, and this was his way of showing me how greatly he appreciated it.

title: Sketches of Travel; or, Twelve Months in Europe
author: King, Horatio
snippet: Pere La Chaise, the Cemetery made famous by thewritings of Lamartine ere special attention had beendirected to the embellishment of burial places in theUnited States, is situated on an eminence in theeastern suburbs of the city, corresponding somewhatwith our Congressional Cemetery, while the Arc deTriomphe, on the western side, may, in point oflocation, be regarded as somewhat correspondingwith our White House, or more nearly with theHeights of Georgetown. The great bulk of the citylies principally on lower ground, between Pere LaChaise and the Arc de Triomphe, extending to thenorth and south of the Seine, which, in its coursethrough the city, separates and forms two considerable islands just east of the Louvre.

title: Forty years on the stage :
author: Barnes, J. H.
snippet: Few cities lend themselves to such a display as Washington does. The place is so beautifully laid out, and Pennsylvania Avenue, with its magnificent width and sweep from the Capitol to the White House, is an ideal street for a procession. On these occasions, this procession extends for miles and takes hours in passing.

title: A Knight Templar abroad; or, Reminiscences of travel beyond the sea
author: Cord, W. Harlan.

TheCanongate was begun in the early part of the twelfthcentury, (and its antique and time-stained buildings,indeed, look much older than that) by the AugustineCanons of Holyrood, who ruled as a burgh of regality,under a charter from King David I., and many of thehouses yet retain the venerable appearance of theancient court end of the city.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: At the end of a man's life sometimes itis healthier than he ever was. Lies have attacked every occupant of theWhite House, have irritated every man since Adam, and every good womansince Eve. Today the lie is after your neighbour; to-morrow it is afteryou.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: Because a railroad company buys up a majority of thelegislature there is no reason why a Governor should sign the charter. There was no reason why the President should make appointments uponindiscriminate claims because the ante-room of the White House wasfilled with applicants, as they were in Cleveland's firstadministration. My sympathies were with the grand army men against thesepretenders.

title: The life of Joseph Hodges Choate as gathered chiefly from his letters,
author: Choate, Joseph Hodges
snippet: I am sure that the President  would gratefully accept it, but he could not control  a place for it in the Senate Chamber, which must depend on the vote of the Senate or of one of its committees. But he could place it in the White House, or very likely it could find a place in the Congressional

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: The Doctor's friendship with President McKinley was an intimate mutualassociation that ended only with the great national disaster of thePresident's assassination. Very often, we walked over in the morning tothe White House to call on the President for an informal chat. A littleschool friend, who was visiting my daughter that winter, told my husbandhow anxious she was to see a President.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: "September 21, 1897. Had a most delightful interview with President    McKinley in the White House.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: I have this afternoon made my last call on President    Cleveland. With Dr. Sunderland and the officers of our church I went    to the White House to bid our retiring President goodbye. Notwithstanding appointments he had made, Thurber, his private    secretary, informed us that the President could not see us because    of a sudden attack of rheumatism.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: In a scrap book in which I put down, hurriedly, perhaps, but accurately,my impressions of various visits to the White House during my four yearspastorate in Washington, I find some notes that may be interesting. Itransmit them to the printed page exactly as I find them written onpaper:

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: It had atone time been the Spanish Legation, and was in a delightful part of thecity. Shortly after my arrival in Washington I received my firstintroduction at the White House, with my daughters, to Mrs. Cleveland. Our reception was cordial and gracious in the extreme.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: I confess to a feeling of pleasure when General Grant, atthe Memorial Services at Greenwood--I think the last public meeting heever attended, and where I delivered the Memorial Address on DecorationDay--said that he had read with interest everything that appearedconnected with my name. President Arthur, at the White House one day,told me the same thing.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: I heard ourrepresentative, Mr. Coombs, speak, and whether his hearers agreed ordisagreed with his sentiments on the tariff question, all realised thathe knew what he was talking about, and his easy delivery and point-blankmanner of statement were impressive. So, also, at the White House,whether people liked the Administration or disliked it, all reasonablepersons agreed that good morals presided over the nation, and thatwell-worn jest about the big hat of the grandfather, President WilliamHenry Harrison, being too ample for the grandson, President BenjaminHarrison, was a witticism that would soon be folded up and put out ofsight. Anybody who had carefully read the 120 addresses delivered byPresident Benjamin Harrison on his tour across the continent knew thathe had three times the brain ever shown by his grandfather.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: Mr. Blaine's visit to the White House to congratulate the victor, hiscordial reception there, and his long stay, was another bright side ofthe election contest. There must have been a good deal of lying aboutthese two men when they were wrestling for the honours, for if all thatwas said had been true the scene of hearty salutation between them wouldnot only have been unfit, but impossible.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: The graceful courtesy with which President Arthur bowed himself out ofthe White House was unparalleled. Never in my memory was a sceptre sogracefully relinquished.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: He faced him on party issues, not as an individualantagonist. The excitement was intense during the suspense that followedthe counting of the ballots, and Mr. Cleveland went into the White Houseamidst a roar of public opinion so confused and so vicious that therewas no certainty of ultimate order in the country. In after years Ienjoyed his confidence and friendship, and I learned to appreciate thestability and reserve of his nature.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: I consider President Garfield was a man with the most brilliant mindwho ever occupied the White House. He had strong health, a splendidphysique, a fine intellect.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: What remembrances come to me, looking backward to this period of ourterrific national carnalism! I shall never forget the first time I eversaw Abraham Lincoln. We followed into his room, at the White House, acommittee that had come to Washington to tell the President how toconduct the war. The saddest-looking man I ever saw was Abraham Lincoln.

title: Scottish Ghost Stories
author: O'Donnell, Elliott
snippet: When she accepted an invitation to a ball, it was alwaysconditionally that Lady Holkitt would put us both up for the night,and the carriage used, then, to come for us the following day, afterone o'clock luncheon. I shall never forget the last time I went to adance at "The Old White House," though it is now rather more thanfifty years ago. My mother had not been very well for some weeks,having, so she thought, taken cold internally.

title: Scottish Ghost Stories
author: O'Donnell, Elliott
snippet: There was once a house, known as "The Old White House," that used tostand by the side of the road, close to where you say the horse firsttook fright. Some people of the name of Holkitt, relations of dear oldSir Arthur Holkitt, and great friends of ours, used to live there.

author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: Irma and I are still in the house above the meadows, andDuncan has just begun to attend Dr. Carson at the High School. We havebeen able to buy the Little White House, and have made manyimprovements, including a couple of servants' bedrooms. But we werejust as happy when I rose to make the fire in the morning, and Mrs.Pathrick came over early on washing days to "get them clothes out on theline at a respectable hour!"

title: The Sunday Philosophy Club
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: Far too gentle for politics. I think that he found himself in the White House by mistake. And he was far too honest.

title: The Charming Quirks of Others
author: McCall Smith, Alexander
snippet: And, indeed, polite American presidents actually engineered excuses to leave the Oval Office for a few moments so that their guests could run round and sit in the President's chair for a few seconds. The only occasion when this had led to embarrassment was when President de Gaulle had visited the White House and had momentarily dropped off to sleep while seated in the President's chair.

title: From an island outpost
author: Waller, Mary E.
snippet: Once it must have been white; now it was the acme of dingy, muddy, grimy, streaked forlornity. It was labelled in huge letters : White House Cafe !

title: My college days,
author: Tomes, Robert
snippet: Stanley was a pleasant companion, and very kind and attentive to us. He took us to the White House, and introduced us to Martin Van Buren, then President of the United States, who, in his usual bland manner, upon my being pre-

title: Library notes,
author: Russell, A. P.
snippet: At the White House, on an occasion I shall never forget, said a visitor, the conversation turned upon religious  subjects, and Lincoln made this impressive remark  : " I have never united myself to any church, be- caus*^ I have found difficulty in giving my assent, without mental reservation, to the long, complicated statements of Christian doctrine which characterize their articles of belief and confessions of faith. When any church will inscribe over its altar, as its sole qualification for membership,"  he continued, " the Saviour's condensed statement of the substance of both law and gospel.

title: Four years in the Old world;
author: Palmer, Phoebe
snippet: that the expenses of our " White House " ai-e less exacting on the purse, if nothing else, than monarchical demands. I must not particularize ; but the reader will forgive the i-ecital of a little that fcomes from a source wholly reliable.

title: Rambles in America, past and present.
author: Pairpoint, Alfred J.
snippet: The other leading public edifice is the White House, or official residence of the President of the United States. This is a somewhat unpretending stone building, two stories high.

title: With the tourist tide,

snippet: One shuts one's eyes upon the waste places, while imagination builds up again the teeming life which animated them in the long ago. Is it possible that men will some day mark the site of our Capitol by a few crumbling walls and search in vain for traces of the White House ?

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: Gilbert and Mr. Priestley made their appearance thatevening in company. The great man was not at allaverse to Mrs. Sage's skilful compliments, and forGilbert the White House was scarcely to be calleda home ; it was not wonderful that he preferred hisstepmother's cheery drawing-room.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: Ralph Patterson turned into the White House withGilbert. The two had been thrown together a gooddeal of late, while Ralph was engaged in the mill, andnow, in his forlorn state, Gilbert found a kind of comfort in the other's strong common sense.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: Nell went off to bed the moment she got back tothe White House. She was too tired for anything, shetold Gilbert over the banisters as she went up.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: Nell read the paper after that—thoroughly, evento the leading articles ; indeed, she read them everyday during her stay at the White House. It was asignificant indication of the straits she was reduced toconversationally, Nell not being in the very leastgiven to politics as a general rule.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: Nevertheless, she was conscious ofsomething very like gratitude to him for the interdictagainst her house. She did not want to be inhospitable, and once she had rather looked forward toexhibiting the glories of the White House to hersister-in-law; but the standpoint had changed since:there were unlooked-for thorns and briars besettingthe path, and visits were hardly likely to be a sourceof unmixed delight on either side. Moreover, Mrs.Tom was not one of those unobtrusive persons whowould be content to slip quietly in and out by someside door.

title: The life of Joseph Hodges Choate as gathered chiefly from his letters,
author: Choate, Joseph Hodges
snippet: Porter to me at Court, saying that she would like to see me at half past four. So as soon as Court adjourned I went again to the White House and saw them both, the poor President having taken his first rest for the day to receive me with her. Then I wound up with five o'clock tea with Mrs. Hay at her husband's request, and all this without a word on either side about anything in particular.

title: The life of Joseph Hodges Choate as gathered chiefly from his letters,
author: Choate, Joseph Hodges
snippet: So I went in and had a talk with him at a little after nine. Then the Attorney General took me to the White House at half past ten to see the President who was very cordial, but as a lot of Senators, all of whom I knew, were surrounding  him and the Cabinet was about to assemble I didn't stop long. He inquired for you and especially for Jo, whose height seems to have made a great impression on him.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]

snippet: Nell had no remembrance of any other habitationthan the White House and the present regime. Shehad come to it a toddling infant, and all her ideasof the world in general were constructed upon itsfoundation, and bounded by Gilbert's opinions.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: Nell was looking about with eager eyes, wondering what had become of the landmarks she usedto know. There was the narrow lane, and there thedear White House, and the open front door—theywere to enter by that to-day, they had not oftentroubled it in old times; there the battered sidegate. But there were strange shrubs and roots inthe flower-beds; new yellow gravel—Mr. Priestley'sown—on the walks ; a tall trim-looking housekeeperat the door, instead of plump Mrs. Burnett.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: "During a conversation of an earlier period at the White House, I    congratulated the President upon his improved appearance since    returning from one of his hunting expeditions.

title: Scottish Ghost Stories
author: O'Donnell, Elliott
snippet: My mother had quite made up her mind to accompanyme to the ball, but at the last moment, the weather being appalling,she yielded to advice, and my aunt Norah, who happened to be stayingwith us at the time, chaperoned me instead. It was snowing when weset out, and as it snowed all through the night and most of the nextday, the roads were completely blocked, and we had to remain at "TheOld White House" from Monday evening till the following Thursday. AuntNorah and I occupied separate bedrooms, and mine was at the end of along passage away from everybody else's.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.

Both Eleanor and Gilbert were wiserthan they had been.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]

Mrs. Sage grew more and morecomplacent, as she reviewed the capabilities of theWhite House under her own directorship.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: A Mrs. Macpherson was at the head ofaffairs now, and kept up a fair amount of comfort andcleanliness. Nell greatly preferred her to the accomplished Taylor; there was more freedom of actionfor the inmates, she could make little re-arrangements of the furniture, fill the old dragon jars withyellow daffodils and brown sycamore buds, and bythe mere fact of her sunny presence, give to theWhite House the first genial, really home-like look ithad worn for nearly a whole generation.

title: T. De Witt Talmage; As I Knew Him
author: Talmage, Eleanor McCutcheon
snippet: "Come on with me, I will show you a real President," said Dr. Talmageone morning, and over we went to the White House. While we were talkingwith the President, Mrs. McKinley came in from a drive and sent wordthat she wished to see us.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: Ralph did not go straight back to his lodgingswhen he left the White House that night; he strayedround to a neglected corner of the garden, and foldedhis arms on the low gate, and stared long and meditatively at the bare triangle where Nell's cherishedleeks had once reared their stately heads.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: While the elders talked, Nell strayed out into thewell-kept garden—a striking contrast to the garden atthe White House, though neither she nor Gilbertwould have exchanged one untidy corner of theirown for the whole range of immaculate perfectionhere. Every square yard of the one had some historyassociated with it: seeds of fabulous virtue that hadbeen sown in faith and hope, and never heard ofagain ; rare ferns and roots, brought with infinite toiland trouble from the deepest recesses of the glen,only to pine and die in their new quarters.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]
author: Pitt, Sarah.
snippet: Miss Craven couldgenerally keep her own counsel—and did. On one of the last days of the old year Christianwas laid away in a corner of the parish kirkyard,within a stone's-throw of the White House gate. Itwas but a small company that gathered round thegrave—Gilbert, Mr. Priestley, Tom Henderson, andRalph Patterson, who was still superintending thesetting up of the new machinery in the mill.

title: White House at Inch Gow, etc. [A tale.]

In a Milestone beyond this, I haverecalled a conversation I had with him at the White House, and recordedmy impressions of him. Above the clamour of these troublesome times, Iraised my voice and said that in the distant years to come the electorsof New York, Alabama, and Maine, and California, would march togetherdown Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington for the discharge of the greatduties of the Electoral College.

snippet: And then other changes had followed, and not forthe better. Mrs. Burnett appeared upon the scene,and took up the reins of government Mrs. Sage hadlaid down, and they had left the busy seaport andbroad river, with its crowds of shipping, and come upto the White House, and the dull manufacturingtown. Gilbert adapted himself to it very comfortablyin course of time: he was not given to fretting afterthe unattainable; but there hovered always a kind ofglamour over those faint early days for him.

Nell did notdare to look up at the effect of her words ; she satdumbly waiting for some avalanche of wrath to fall,and unconsciously trying to recall what had happened, when he was expelled from the White Housegarden for much the same reason, that far-awaySaturday afternoon.

title: Famous persons and places.
author: Willis, Nathaniel Parker
snippet: "Whatever  veneration existed in the minds of the people toward the former, their curiosity in reference to the latter predominated, unquestionably. The circular pave, extending from the gate to the White House, was thronged with citizens of all classes, those coming away having each a small brown paper parcel and a very strong smell ; those advancing manifesting, by shakings of the head and frequent exclamations, that there may be too much of a good thing, and particularly of a cheese. The beautiful portico was thronged with boys and coach drivers, and the odor strengthened with every step.
